docs.abstract: The company showed off a slate of new computers with better screens, faster processors and higher price tags.
docs.snippet: The company showed off a slate of new computers with better screens, faster processors and higher price tags.
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple showed off a slate of new computers with better screens, faster processors and higher price tags on Tuesday, including an iPad Pro that the company is trying to position as a primary work computer.

headline.main: Apple Unveils New iPad and MacBook Air
headline.print_headline: Apple Pushes Newest iPad  As a Main Work Computer

docs.abstract: Profits rose by nearly a third in the latest quarter, Apple said, news that could soon make the tech giant the first public company worth more than $1 trillion.
docs.snippet: Profits rose by nearly a third in the latest quarter, Apple said, news that could soon make the tech giant the first public company worth more than $1 trillion.
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple reported another strong quarter of profits on Tuesday, as consumers kept buying iPhones and paying more for them, news that could soon help make the Silicon Valley giant the first public company to be worth more than $1 trillion.

headline.main: Apple Could Soon Be Worth $1 Trillion as Profits Pour In
headline.print_headline: More Profits Could Send Apple Past $1 Trillion

docs.abstract: While Google, Facebook and Twitter face scrutiny for spreading misinformation, Apple has avoided scandal by using people to pick what news to show. Is that good for news outlets?
docs.snippet: While Google, Facebook and Twitter face scrutiny for spreading misinformation, Apple has avoided scandal by using people to pick what news to show. Is that good for news outlets?
docs.lead_paragraph: Many of Apple’s employees moved into a glistening new $5 billion glass headquarters in Cupertino, Calif., this year. A mile west, at Apple’s old campus on 1 Infinite Loop, a project antithetical to Silicon Valley’s ethos is now underway.

headline.main: Apple News’s Radical Approach: Humans Over Machines
headline.print_headline: A Human Touch At Apple News

docs.abstract: People are increasingly calling for boycotts of the big tech companies amid a backlash. The problem is that Facebook, Apple, Amazon and Google are nearly inescapable.
docs.snippet: People are increasingly calling for boycotts of the big tech companies amid a backlash. The problem is that Facebook, Apple, Amazon and Google are nearly inescapable.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Ryan Knight, a Democratic activist in Los Angeles, called for a boycott of Apple in February because it hadn’t responded to calls to delete a channel from the National Rifle Association from its streaming-video service after the Parkland, Fla., school shooting.

headline.main: They Tried to Boycott Facebook, Apple and Google. They Failed.

docs.abstract: Apple’s C.E.O. slammed his Silicon Valley peers for building a “data industrial complex” but his speech requires context.
docs.snippet: Apple’s C.E.O. slammed his Silicon Valley peers for building a “data industrial complex” but his speech requires context.
docs.lead_paragraph: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

headline.main: The Week in Tech: Apple Goes on the Attack
headline.print_headline: Apple Chief Has Harsh Words for Tech Rivals

docs.abstract: The iPhone maker’s stock is down 20 percent this month, shaving about $230 billion off its market value. Microsoft’s stock, meanwhile, is up 1 percent.
docs.snippet: The iPhone maker’s stock is down 20 percent this month, shaving about $230 billion off its market value. Microsoft’s stock, meanwhile, is up 1 percent.

headline.print_headline: Apple’s Bad Month Gets Worse, As Value Falls by $230 Billion

docs.abstract: The week started with a surprise in the manufacturing sector and ended with new Silicon Valley revelations.
docs.snippet: The week started with a surprise in the manufacturing sector and ended with new Silicon Valley revelations.
docs.lead_paragraph: Hi there! I’m Zach Wichter. Charlotte Cowles is off, so I’m bringing you the gist of business news from the week that was and the week to come. I’ll look really good if I can get more new subscribers than Charlotte normally pulls in, so help me out by clicking here.

headline.main: This Week in Business: G.M. Idles Plants, and Sundar Pichai Goes to Washington

docs.abstract: Life is a lot easier when you can plug in to any socket.
docs.snippet: Life is a lot easier when you can plug in to any socket.
docs.lead_paragraph: Our modern existence depends on things we can take for granted. Cars run on gas from any gas station, the plugs for electrical devices fit into any socket, and smartphones connect to anything equipped with Bluetooth. All of these conveniences depend on technical standards, the silent and often forgotten foundations of technological societies.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: National Institute of Standards and Technology

byline.original: By Andrew Russell and Lee Vinsel

docs.abstract: Widely available services offer a range of spying abilities, including tracking people’s phones and harvesting their texts. As survivors seek help, the legal and technical hurdles are many.
docs.snippet: Widely available services offer a range of spying abilities, including tracking people’s phones and harvesting their texts. As survivors seek help, the legal and technical hurdles are many.
docs.lead_paragraph: KidGuard is a phone app that markets itself as a tool for keeping tabs on children. But it has also promoted its surveillance for other purposes and run blog posts with headlines like “How to Read Deleted Texts on Your Lover’s Phone.”

headline.main: Hundreds of Apps Can Empower Stalkers to Track Their Victims
headline.print_headline: How a Stalker Can Be Hiding In Your Pocket
